{"timeCrawl": "15:35:00", "uri": "710966594", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:35:00Z", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "source": {"title": "iowapublicradio.org", "uri": "iowapublicradio.org", "id": "5475"}, "url": "http://iowapublicradio.org/post/trump-defends-beauty-confederate-memorials", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "President Trump stood by his heavily criticized defense of monuments commemorating the Confederacy in a series of tweets Thursday morning. Trump said removing the statues of Confederate generals meant removing \"beauty\" -- that would \"never able to be comparably replaced\" -- from American cities. As he did in a Tuesday press conference, he also attempted to equate some Confederate generals with some of the Founding Fathers.\n\nStrung together, the tweets read:\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\" [ellipses removed for clarity]\n\nWhite House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters declined to discuss the tweets with reporters on Thursday morning, saying, \"The tweets speak for themselves.\"\n\nThe tweets come after days of the president whipsawing back and forth on his response to the violence in Charlottesville, Va., that led to the death of 32-year-old Heather Heyer after a man who had attended the white supremacist rally drove his car into a crowd of counterprotesters.\n\nShortly after that incident, Trump condemned both the white nationalist protesters and the counterprotesters, saying there was an \"egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides, on many sides.\"\n\nAfter Democrats and Republicans alike castigated him for those remarks, the president came out more forcefully against racist groups on Monday, declaring that \"racism is evil\" and characterizing members of the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazis as \"criminals and thugs.\"\n\nBut Trump's impromptu remarks at a Tuesday press conference -- originally intended to focus on infrastructure -- represented a strong swing back to his original position, which suggested equivalency between white supremacist groups and the \"alt-right,\" on the one hand, and the groups who opposed them like Black Lives Matter and leftist anti-facist protesters, on the other hand.\n\nAround half of Americans -- 52 percent -- believe the president's response to the violence in Charlottesville was \"not strong enough,\" according to an NPR/Marist poll released Wednesday. Only 27 percent said it was strong enough (the remainder were unsure).\n\nThose views shift heavily by party -- a majority of Republicans, 59 percent, say the president's response was strong enough (compared with 10 percent of Democrats). Meanwhile, an overwhelming majority of Democrats -- 79 percent -- believe the response was not strong enough (compared with 19 percent of Republicans).\n\nHowever, more than 60 percent of Americans also believe that statues honoring the Confederacy should \"remain as a historical symbol,\" according to that NPR/Marist poll. And while there is also a partisan divide here, a sizable share of Democrats, 44 percent, believe those statues should remain (along with 86 percent of Republicans and 61 percent of independents).\n\nDebate over removal of Confederate memorials has spread nationwide in recent years. While defenders say that such memorials simply represent a part of the nation's history, the monuments and statues are for many Americans a reminder of the nation's painful history of slavery and the people who fought to defend it.\n\nIn a widely circulated May speech on his city's removal of four statues commemorating the Confederacy, New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu, a Democrat, explained why he believed that removing the memorials was necessary.\n\n\"These statues are not just stone and metal,\" he said. \"They are not just innocent remembrances of a benign history. These monuments purposefully celebrate a fictional, sanitized Confederacy; ignoring the death, ignoring the enslavement, and the terror that it actually stood for.\"", "id": "9722989", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "02:56:00", "uri": "711219922", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:56:00Z", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "source": {"title": "HeraldNet.com", "uri": "heraldnet.com", "id": "10395"}, "url": "http://www.heraldnet.com/news/under-fire-from-gop-trump-digs-in-on-confederate-icons/", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. -- With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nAnd the White House said Thursday that it was abandoning plans to form an infrastructure advisory council.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. {"timeCrawl": "03:54:00", "uri": "711234058", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:54:00Z", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "source": {"title": "The Times of India", "uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "id": "1185"}, "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/donald-trump-says-slavery-part-of-us-history-removing-its-symbols-is-foolish/articleshow/60107966.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "WASHINGTON: President Donald Trump has ripped open a can of worms the United States has long put a lid on. Notwithstanding its self-professed tag of being the world's greatest democracy, the country's founders were slave-owners, and white supremacists - many of whom adore Trump for his unabashedly nativist stance - idolize and idealize the country's dark past, including celebrating Southern Confederate generals who opposed the end of slavery.\n\nNone of this is a secret, but Trump has stirred latent unrest over the country's past. In yet another series of controversial tweets on Thursday morning, the US President argued that White supremacists and nativists protesting the removal of Confederate monuments (celebrating pro-slavery figures) were not wrong because it was part of the country's history that could not be changed, and those who were pressing for the removal of such monuments were \"foolish.\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" Trump tweeted, further roiling a country that is already inflamed by debate on slavery and racism after violent clashes between all-white, alt-right elements seeking, like Trump, to preserve - and in some cases celebrate -- the country's dark past, and left-liberal activists seeking to erase it.\n\n\"So foolish! Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\" Trump continued, invoking names of Confederate heroes Robert Lee and Stonewall Jackson, whose monuments and memorials are being removed in many US cities and states that have rejected racist white hypernationalism.\n\nIronically, even descendants of Lee and Jackson are saying they have no problem with statues of their forbears being taken down or mothballed.\n\n\"Maybe it's appropriate to have them in museums or to put them in some sort of historical context in that regard,\" Gen. Lee's great-great-grandson Robert E Lee told CNN. \"In a public place, if it is offensive and people are taking issue with it, let's move it. Let's put it somewhere where historically it fits with the area around it so you can have people come to see it, who want to understand that history and that individual,\" added Bertram Hayes-Davis, great-great-grandson of Confederate president Jefferson Davis.\n\nMonuments, roads, and highways named after Confederate heroes abound in South-Eastern United States, including in and around Washington DC. But they are gradually being removed in cities such as Baltimore, New Orleans, and Atlanta, where these are seen as an abrasive reminder to blacks and liberals of the country's dark past.\n\nConversely, the monuments have become a rallying point for white supremacists who believed they are being marginalized in a country they think they own and belongs only to them.\n\nSuch supremacists, including reactionary and extremist Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazis, constituted a large segment of the alt-right rally in Charlottesville last week that degenerated into violence, and resulted in the mowing down of a liberal counter-demonstrator by a white extremist. Although Trump condemned the murder and expressed admiration for the liberal activist, the rest of his remarks and arguments are widely seen as being sympathetic to the all-white, alt-right cause - which also constitutes his primary voting base.\n\nIn fact, the Lee family went so far as to condemn the ugly and racist rally that President Trump has repeatedly tried to rationalize and justify. \"At the end of the Civil War, he (Gen Lee) implored the nation to come together to heal our wounds and to move forward to become a more unified nation,\" the family said in a statement referring to events in Charlottesville. \"He never would have tolerated the hateful words and violent actions of white supremacists, the KKK, or neo-Nazis.\"\n\nBut Trump insists that he is against the bigotry and hate expressed at the rally even as his own partymen are mortified and shamed by his statements. As usual, he is also blaming the media for \"misrepresenting\" statements that white extremists have been celebrating.\n\n\"The public is learning (even more so) how dishonest the Fake News is. They totally misrepresent what I say about hate, bigotry etc. Shame!\" he raged on Twitter, lashing out at Republican Senator Lindsey Graham for concluding that Trump has drawn a moral equivalency between the KKK, neo-Nazis & white supremacists, and the slain protester.\n\nThe looming question before the United States is where all this will end. As has increasingly become the pattern, Trump is heading out to his support base in Middle America for succor, even as the coastal liberals disdain him. \"Join me at 7:00 P.M. on Tuesday, August 22nd in Phoenix, Arizona at the Phoenix Convention Center!\" he announced Thursday on Twitter.\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for {"timeCrawl": "01:35:00", "uri": "711199201", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:35:00Z", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "source": {"title": "timesfreepress.com", "uri": "timesfreepress.com", "id": "3418"}, "url": "http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/breakingnews/story/2017/aug/17/under-fire-gop-trump-digs-confederate-icons/444142/", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. {"timeCrawl": "15:26:00", "uri": "710962716", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:26:00Z", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "source": {"title": "keranews.org", "uri": "keranews.org", "id": "4728"}, "url": "http://keranews.org/post/trump-defends-beauty-confederate-memorials", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "President Donald Trump stood by his heavily criticized defense of monuments commemorating the Confederacy in a series of tweets Thursday morning. Trump said that removing the statues of Confederate generals meant removing \"beauty\" -- that would \"never able to be comparably replaced\" -- from American cities. As he did in a Tuesday press conference, he also attempted to equate some Confederate generals with some of the Founding Fathers.\n\nStrung together, the tweets read:\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\" [ellipses removed for clarity]\n\nWhite House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters declined to discuss the tweets with reporters on Thursday morning, saying, \"The tweets speak for themselves.\"\n\nThe tweets come after days of the president whipsawing back and forth on his response to the violence in Charlottesville, Va., that led to the death of 32-year-old Heather Heyer after a man drove his car into a crowd of counterprotesters.\n\nShortly after that incident, Trump condemned both the white nationalist protesters and the counterprotesters, saying there was an \"egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides, on many sides.\"\n\nAfter Democrats and Republicans alike castigated him for those remarks, the president came out more forcefully against racist groups, declaring that \"racism is evil\" and characterizing members of the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazis as \"criminals and thugs.\"\n\nBut Trump's impromptu remarks at a Tuesday press conference -- originally intended to focus on infrastructure -- represented a strong swing back to his original position, which suggested equivalency between white supremacist group and the alt-right, on the one hand, and the groups who opposed them like Black Lives Matter and leftist antifa protesters, on the other hand.\n\nAround half of Americans -- 52 percent -- believe the president's response to the violence in Charlottesville was \"not strong enough,\" according to an NPR/Marist poll released Wednesday. Only 27 percent said it was strong enough (the remainder were unsure).\n\nThose views shift heavily by party -- a majority of Republicans, 59 percent, say the president's response was strong enough (compared to 10 percent of Democrats). Meanwhile, an overwhelming majority of Democrats -- 79 percent -- believe the response was not strong enough (compared to 19 percent of Republicans).\n\nHowever, nearly two-thirds of Americans do also believe that statues honoring the confederacy should \"remain as a historical symbol,\" according to that NPR/Marist poll. And while there's also a partisan divide here, a sizable share of Democrats, 44 percent, believe those statues should remain (along with 86 percent of Republicans and 61 percent of independents).\n\nDebate over removal of Confederate memorials has spread nationwide in recent years. While defenders say that such memorials simply represent a part of the nation's history, the monuments and statues are for many Americans a reminder of the nation's painful history of slavery and the people who fought to defend it.\n\nIn a widely circulated May speech on his city's removal of four statues commemorating the Confederacy, New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu, a Democrat, explained why he believed that removing the memorials was necessary.\n\n\"These statues are not just stone and metal,\" he said. \"They are not just innocent remembrances of a benign history. These monuments purposefully celebrate a fictional, sanitized Confederacy; ignoring the death, ignoring the enslavement, and the terror that it actually stood for.\"", "id": "9721441", "details": {}, {"timeCrawl": "16:35:00", "uri": "710998035", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:55:00Z", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "source": {"title": "Reason.com", "uri": "reason.com", "id": "4573"}, "url": "http://reason.com/blog/2017/08/17/trumps-idea-of-uniting-the-country-compl", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "But guess what happens whenever art gets in the way of one of his developments?\n\nAnother Twitter flare-up from President Donald Trump this morning is going to command the news cycle for the day. Trump began ranting about Republican Sens. Lindsey Graham (South Carolina) and Jeff Flake (Arizona), consistent critics of Trump's behavior. Trump called Graham a publicity seeker and expressed happiness that Flake was facing a primary opponent.\n\nAnd then Trump decided to wade back into the Confederate monument debate, after having been blasted on all sides yesterday. A trio of tweets to get your morning started:\n\nSad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You..... -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\n...can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also... -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\n...the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 17, 2017\n\nTrump knows all about removing art that will be missed and cannot be replaced. When Trump was building his tower in New York City he had destroyed art deco friezes a museum wanted to preserve because it delayed the demolition of a skyscraper that needed to come down.\n\nTrump also has a monument to a civil war battle that never happened at his golf club in Virginia.\n\nAs for the slippery slope contention -- that this will lead to the tearing down of non-Confederate memorials because people are offended -- Eric Boehm and Ronald Bailey have both explained effectively here at Reason how easy it is to draw a line between American historical figures who have owned slaves or have done other bad things versus those who waged war with the United States in order to preserve slavery.\n\nIt is worth noting that Trump is hardly an outlier in not wanting monuments to come down. An NPR poll released this week showed that 62 percent of Americans want these statues to remain \"as a historical symbol.\" A remarkable nugget from the poll: Even more African Americans (44 percent) want them to remain than want them removed (40 percent). Unsurprisingly, more African Americans were unsure what to do with them (16 percent) than white people (8 percent) or Latino people (11 percent) polled.\n\nThere are many ways to interpret these results that have nothing to do with support for the Confederacy. The results may say more about the unease of many Americans with what appears to be censorship (even when it's not actually censorship).\n\nPerhaps it would be easier if these statues were not in the hands of government, and the social cost of the controversy shouldered by private individuals. And as an added bonus, it wouldn't cost taxpayers to deal with it. I joked on Twitter that cities should sell the Confederate statues to people who care so much about preserving them and redistribute the money back to its citizens.\n\nIn Los Angeles, a memorial for Confederate soldiers at Hollywood Forever Cemetery was just removed at the request of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, the group who placed the marker there at the 1920s. Yes, there was some social pressure to remove it, obviously, but private people making the decision about whether to display such a memorial is preferable to government officials deciding the correct On Thursday morning he took his apologist rhetoric to Twitter, reiterating his position on monuments celebrating pro-slavery generals. In several tweets, Trump defended the \"beauty\" of Confederate monuments, declaring that American history and culture was \"being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments.\"\n\nThis was an echo of his comments from his provocative Tuesday press conference, when he asked, \"I wonder, is it George Washington next week?\" He also posited that monuments to Thomas Jefferson could soon go. Both owned slaves, but neither rebelled against the country's government that they helped establish as Founding Fathers. His views on Twitter, though, are perhaps even more unprecedented, to use the word of the week.\n\nThis will further alienate Trump from other Republicans who have all but universally condemned white supremacists in the wake of the Charlottesville violence that resulted in three deaths and dozens injured. They've also doubled down on it after Trump tried to place the blame on \"many\" and \"both sides.\" The comments have already stirred debate online, with some 30,000 replies in the first hour of them going up, and other politicians are sure to weigh in.\n\nThe Unite the Right rally was first planned in response to moves to take down a statue of Robert E. Lee from a Charlottesville park. This week Baltimore removed statues of both Lee and Thomas J. \"Stonewall\" Jackson, two generals who fought for the South, as well as one of Supreme Court Chief Justice Roger B. Taney. Taney wrote the 1857 Dred Scott decision, which found African-Americans were not guaranteed equal rights because of bigotry that existed at the time the Constitution was written. It was later overturned.\n\nTrump and other modern Confederate sympathizers have spoken about history when trying to defend the monuments. But the history that they really speak to is the backlash against Reconstruction and the Civil Rights Movement, as a recent article in Vox proves. An infographic from the Southern Poverty Law Center shows that the vast majority of the statues were put up in the years immediately following both advances in rights for African Americans.\n\nSomething that represents the fight to continue the enslavement of Americans is not \"beautiful.\" The monuments' public display is at best contentious, and Trump should listen to his aides, who are surely as shocked as you are. {"timeCrawl": "19:37:00", "uri": "711077290", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:57:00Z", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/us/trump-sad-to-see-history-ripped-apart-with-removal-of-beautiful-statues-1.3189622", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "Under fire for defending racist activist groups, US president Donald Trump has said on Twitter that he was \"sad\" to see United States's history torn apart by the removal of \"our beautiful statues and monuments,\".\n\nThis echoes a popular refrain of white supremacist groups that oppose the removal of Confederate monuments.\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\" Mr Trump posted on Twitter on Thursday.\n\nOfficials in several states have called for the removal of public monuments that have become symbols of the Confederacy.\n\nThe Twitter posts were the latest in his escalating remarks that critics contend validates white supremacist groups who led a bloody rally over the weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nThe proposed removal of a statute of the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee from a public park in Charlottesville spurred the demonstrations.\n\nOn Saturday, the day of the protests, Mr Trump did not condemn neo-Nazis or white supremacists in his public remarks about the violence, prompting criticism that his omission suggested support for the racist groups.\n\nAn Ohio man with white supremacist ties is accused of driving his car into a crowd, killing one woman and injuring 19 other people. Two days later, Mr Trump bowed to pressure and said racism was \"evil\" and named racist organisations in his follow-up remarks about Charlottesville.\n\nBut on Tuesday, Mr Trump reverted to his initial public posture and blamed \"both sides\" for the violence.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham repeated his criticism of the president's actions in a series of Twitter posts after Mr Trump tweeted that Mr Graham was \"publicity seeking.\"\n\n\"Because of the manner in which you have handled the Charlottesville tragedy you are now receiving praise from some of the most racist and hate-filled individuals and groups in our country. For the sake of our Nation, as our President, please fix this,\" Mr Graham wrote on Twitter.\n\nOther Republicans, including the most powerful in Congress, have been making strong statements on Charlottesville and racism, but few have been mentioning Mr Trump himself. The Senate's top Republican, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, condemned \"hate and bigotry\". House Speaker Paul Ryan said that \"white supremacy is repulsive\". But neither criticised the president's insistence that there were \"very fine people on both sides\" of the violent weekend clash in Virginia. The nuanced statements reflect the party establishment's delicate dance. Few top Republican officeholders want to defend the president in the midst of an escalating political crisis, yet they are unwilling to declare all-out opposition to him and risk alienating his loyalists.\n\nIn another major sign of discontent within the Republican Party, Mr Trump abruptly abolished two of his White House business councils on Wednesday as corporate chiefs began resigning in protest over his racial statements.\n\n\"Rather than putting pressure on the business people of the Manufacturing Council & Strategy & Policy Forum, I am ending both. Thank you all!\" Mr Trump tweeted from New York.\n\nHis action came after one of the panels had already agreed to disband earlier in the day. The White House is trying to deal with the repercussions from Mr Trump's defiant remarks on the Virginia tragedy.\n\nAdvisers hunkered down, offering no public defence while privately expressing frustration with his comments. But Mr Trump himself, staying at his golf club in New Jersey, was increasing rather than slowing his tweet-a-thon.\n\nOn Wednesday, he had told associates he was pleased with how his combative press conference had gone a day earlier, saying he believed he had effectively stood up to the media, according to three people familiar with the conversations.", "id": "9764206", "details": {}, "date": {"timeCrawl": "01:42:00", "uri": "711200879", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:11:00Z", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "source": {"title": "Virginian-Pilot", "uri": "pilotonline.com", "id": "9350"}, "url": "http://pilotonline.com/news/government/politics/under-fire-from-gop-trump-digs-in-on-confederate-icons/article_9fe7529a-85f6-513a-b32c-2ebebafb3664.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nAnd the White House said Thursday that it was abandoning plans to form an infrastructure advisory council.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nSign up now and get breaking news alerts delivered to your inbox.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n-- -- --\n\nLemire reported from New York. {"timeCrawl": "13:03:00", "uri": "711453636", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T13:03:00Z", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "source": {"title": "DiversityInc", "uri": "diversityinc.com", "id": "7469"}, "url": "http://www.diversityinc.com/news/confederate-monuments-trump/", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "After equating activists for equality to neo-Nazis following the violence in Charlottesville, President Donald Trump has continued to double down on his racist rhetoric.\n\nSad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You.....\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\n...can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also...\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\n...the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 17, 2017\n\n\"The tweets speak for themselves,\" a White House spokeswoman said to reporters on Thursday.\n\nTrump's words come at a time when leaders across the country are removing Confederate monuments from public spaces, recognizing their historical ties to racism, and when even the president's fellow Republicans are unable to defend him.\n\nMany people do believe that Confederate monuments should remain in tact \"as a historical symbol.\" A new Marist poll found that 67 percent of Americans feel this way. And a YouGov poll found that 67 percent of Americans believe Confederate monuments represent \"Southern pride,\" while only 26 percent link them with racism.\n\nHowever, this changes when broken down by race, suggesting that Trump is taking only one group of Americans into consideration when talking about the history of the \"beautiful\" statues.\n\nAccording to the Marist poll, Black Americans are almost evenly divided on whether the monuments should stay or be removed. Forty-four percent believe they should not be removed, while 40 percent said they should be. The YouGov poll, meanwhile, found that 47 percent of Blacks perceive the monuments as symbols of racism and 17 percent connect them to Southern pride. Thirty-five percent were not sure.\n\nCities in California, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, New York, North Carolina, Massachusetts, Missouri, Montana, Tennessee, Virginia, and Texas, as well as Washington, D.C., have all either removed statues and monuments pertaining to the Confederacy or are considering doing so.\n\nThis week Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh had four Confederate monuments removed: a Confederate Soldiers and Sailors monument, a Confederate Women's monument, a statue of Lee and Jackson and a statue of Supreme Court Justice Roger Taney. Taney authored the decision in the Dred Scott v. Stanford case, in which Dred Scott, who was enslaved, sued for his freedom. In the 7-2 ruling led by Taney, the court rejected his request.\n\nThe removals were done in the middle of the night, drawing less public attention and trying to prevent any clashes with protesters.\n\nMaryland's Republican Gov. Larry Hogan this week expressed his support for removing the Taney statue. Notably, he had a very different opinion in 2015 -- one more similar to Trump's. At the time he pointed to the history tied to Confederate monuments.\n\n\"Where do we draw the line?\" he said at the time. \"Some of this is our history. We hear people saying we should dig up the Confederate cemeteries in Maryland.\"\n\n\"George Washington was a slave owner,\" Hogan also said. \"Should we remove him from the statehouse?\"\n\nWhile Maryland was a slave state during the Civil War era, it was considered a Border state. Most of its soldiers fought for the North, though.\n\nMeanwhile, Trump's fellow Republicans have been distancing themselves from him amid his numerous offensive and racist statements over the days following Charlottesville.\n\nSen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) called into question Trump's competence to fulfill his duties as POTUS.\n\n\"The president has not yet been able to demonstrate the ability or the competence that he needs to be successful,\" Corker said.\n\n\"He has not demonstrated that he understands what has made this nation great and what it is today, and he's got to demonstrate the characteristics of a president who understands that,\" he also said. \"And without the things that I just mentioned happening, our nation is going to go through great peril.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina, the only Black Republican senator, said in an interview with VICE on Thursday that Trump's comments this week compromise the \"clarity and moral authority\" people need to see from a president.\n\nTrump took to Twitter to attack Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), saying that the senator was speaking out against the president only for \"publicity.\"\n\nGraham responded in a series of tweets.\n\nMr. President, like most I seek to move our nation, my state, and our party forward - toward the light - not back to the darkness. (1) https://t.co/K1j4JnhCgf\n\n-- Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 17, 2017\n\nHowever, because of the manner in which you have handled the Charlottesville tragedy you are now receiving praise from some.....(3)\n\n-- Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 17, 2017\n\n....you are now receiving praise from some of the most racist and hate-filled individuals and groups in our country. (4)\n\n-- Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC) August 17, 2017\n\nThe debate of what Confederacy symbolizes in today's society was largely reawakened after white supremacist Dylann Roof murdered nine Black parishioners at a historically Black church in South Carolina. Photos of Roof later surfaced with Confederate memorabilia.\n\nIn May New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu delivered a powerful speech after the last of four Confederate monuments were taken down in his city. He believes New Orleans, which he describes as \"truly a city of many nations, a melting pot\" and is also \"rooted in a diverse people who have been here together every step of the way,\" is better for it.\n\n\"These monuments purposefully celebrate a fictional, sanitized Confederacy, ignoring the death, ignoring the enslavement and the terror that it actually stood for,\" Landrieu said in a powerful speech on Friday.\n\nTo those who tie the Confederacy to history, Landrieu points to a much darker part of history that is often left out of the conversation:\n\n\"And it immediately begs the questions, why there are no slave ship monuments, no prominent markers on public land to remember the lynchings or the slave blocks; nothing to remember this long chapter of our lives; the pain, the sacrifice, the shame... all of it happening on the soil of New Orleans. So for those self-appointed defenders of history and the monuments, they are eerily silent on what amounts to this historical malfeasance, a lie by omission. There is a difference between remembrance of history and reverence of it.\"\n\nThe statues were not erected in honor of history -- they were erected \"to rewrite history to hide the truth, which is that the Confederacy was on the wrong side of humanity,\" Landrieu said.", "id": "9898148", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Confederate Monuments' Removal Was 'Foolish,' Says Trump | {"timeCrawl": "01:49:00", "uri": "711203166", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:19:00Z", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "source": {"title": "WTOP", "uri": "wtop.com", "id": "6602"}, "url": "http://wtop.com/virginia/2017/08/trump-increasingly-isolated-as-business-panels-dismantled/", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nAnd the White House said Thursday that it was abandoning plans to form an infrastructure advisory council.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n___\n\nLemire reported from New York. Associated Press writer Julie Bykowicz in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "19:12:00", "uri": "711066345", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:12:00Z", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "source": {"title": "WBUR FM 90.9", "uri": "wbur.org", "id": "1593"}, "url": "http://www.wbur.org/radioboston/2017/08/17/confederate-monument-boston", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "Today, President Trump sent out a series of three tweets saying, \"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish! Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\nThe president's tweets come in the wake of his many controversial statements since the violence in Charlottesville. And they also come amid the removal this week of Confederate monuments by the mayor of Baltimore, and the removal, by activists, of a statue of a Confederate soldier in North Carolina.\n\nBut it's not only our southern neighbors who have to deal with Confederate monuments.\n\nHere in Boston, the state's only Confederate monument has been boarded up since June, when the governor said he wanted it taken down. The state is trying to figure out how to remove it, given it's part of a national historic landmark.\n\nThe granite block, which sits outside Fort Warren on Georges Island in Boston Harbor, lists thirteen Confederate soldiers who died there as prisoners.\n\nBarbara Berenson, author of \"Boston In The Civil War: Hub Of The Second Revolution\" and \"Walking Tours Of Civil War Boston: Hub Of Abolitionism.\"\n\nMichael Jeffries, associate professor of American Studies at Wellesley and author of \"Paint the White House Black: Barack Obama and the Meaning of Race in America.\" He tweets {"timeCrawl": "01:14:00", "uri": "711193430", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:14:00Z", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "source": {"title": "WSOC", "uri": "wsoctv.com", "id": "497"}, "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/national-news/ap-top-news/trump-increasingly-isolated-as-business-panels-dismantled/594067812", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "Out of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons - bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nAnd the White House said Thursday that it was abandoning plans to form an infrastructure advisory council.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard - against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday - insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous - Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post - but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n___\n\nLemire reported from New York. {"timeCrawl": "22:54:00", "uri": "711152383", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:54:00Z", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "source": {"title": "The Epoch Times", "uri": "theepochtimes.com", "id": "119"}, "url": "http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2282745-movement-to-remove-confederate-statues-expanding/", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "A statue on the portal of Duke University Chapel bearing the likeness of Confederate General Robert E. Lee was vandalized on early Aug. 17, 2017 in Durham, North Carolina. This is the latest instance of Confederate statues and monuments being removed, vandalized, or destroyed. (Sara D. Davis/Getty Images)\n\nGroups of far-left protesters are tearing down and vandalizing historical statues and monuments they deem antithetical to their views. They began by targeting Confederate statues and monuments, and have now expanded their efforts to include those of other historical figures, with some analysts saying their real goal is to tear down the legitimacy of the American founding.\n\nIn Durham, North Carolina, a mob tore down a statue of a Confederate soldier on Aug. 14, and on Aug. 17 an unknown individual vandalized a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee.\n\nIn Atlanta, Georgia, another mob of protesters vandalized the Peace Monument which depicts an angel directing a Confederate soldier to lay down his weapon.\n\nIn other parts of the country, including in Florida and Baltimore, local government officials are having Confederate statues removed. And in San Antonia, Texas, local officials are looking to remove a statue of a famous leader at the Alamo, which some have allegedly mistaken for a Confederate statue.\n\nThe efforts of the far left are moving beyond Confederate statues to include those of other historical figures as well.\n\nAn unknown assailant vandalized the Lincoln Memorial on Aug. 15, in Washington, using red spray paint to leave the phrase \"F*** Law.\" In Chicago, a bust of Abraham Lincoln erected in 1926 was found defaced and burned. Lincoln was the head of the Republican Party and the leader of the Union, which fought against the Confederates.\n\nAngela Rye, a commentator for CNN, political analyst for NPR, and head of her own political advocacy firm in Washington, D.C., has called for tearing down the statues of George Washington and Thomas Jefferson, because these founding fathers were slave owners.\n\nOn CNN on Aug. 17 during a heated discussion she said, \"I don't care if it's a George Washington statue or a Thomas Jefferson statue, they all need to come down.\"\n\nIn his press conference on Aug. 15, Trump had warned that the statues of George Washington and Thomas Jefferson would be next as the demand for removing Confederate statues expanded.\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted on the morning of Aug. 17: \"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments. You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish!\"\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\" Trump tweeted.\n\nA poll released by NPR, PBS, NewsHour, and Marist on Aug. 16 found that 62 percent of Americans believe that \"statues honoring leaders of the Confederacy,\" should \"remain as a historical symbol.\" It found that only 27 percent of respondents believed the statues should be removed.\n\nThe efforts to tear down the statues received additional fuel after violent protests in Charlottesville, Virginia, where a group that included white supremacists protested plans to tear down the statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee.\n\nThe protests turned violent after a group of anarchist-communist protesters with Antifa arrived with weapons and launched attacks, and a female protester was killed after a man crashed into two cars at an intersection filled with pedestrians -- an incident that is still being investigated.\n\nJohn Daniel Davidson, a senior correspondent at The Federalist, gave his analysis on the recent events during an Aug. 15 segment on Fox News with Tucker Carlson.\n\n\"This has been coming down the pipe for a number of years,\" Davidson said, noting that in April 2015, around the 150th anniversary of the Confederate surrender at Appomattox, some far-left news outlets in the mainstream media were even calling for the desecration of Confederate graves.\n\nHe compared the recent developments to the Cultural Revolution under the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), from 1966 to 1976, where people were directed to destroy their historical relics and traditional culture. It was led by Mao Zedong, history's most prolific mass murderer, credited with killing 60 to 70 million Chinese people.\n\n\"If you want to see where tearing down statues by mobs will get you, look at pictures of China's Cultural Revolution, where they tore down statues, temples, the whole thing -- even stomping on them,\" Davidson said.\n\nHe added, however, that it appears the protesters aren't necessarily just against the ideas of the Confederates. Rather, he said, \"They're trying to delegitimize the U.S. government and the traditions of American society because they don't believe in them.\"\n\n\"This is not about the Confederacy,\" he said. \"This is not about the Civil War. Thousands of protesters crowded the streets around Trump Tower before U.S. President Donald Trump's first visit to the building since taking office on Monday. (Xinhua/Li Muzi)\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday took to Twitter to decry the removal of confederate statues across the United States, saying the move was \"foolish\".\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" Trump said in the first of three consecutive tweets.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it. Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson-who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish!\" Trump said, reiterating his previous remarks.\n\nTrump first put the country's founders alongside confederate generals in a heated press conference Tuesday, saying a recent trend to remove confederate monuments would extend to Washington and Jefferson, who were also slave owners.\n\nSimilar rhetoric has been voiced by white nationalists groups, who said U.S. history is at stake.\n\n\"What are we going to name our capital city, Washington D.C, Huge Slaver?\" Jared Taylor, editor of white nationalist group American Renaissance told CNN in an interview.\n\nBut the analogy has been rebuked by historians, saying that the most kind explanation of Trump's view was \"ignorance\".\n\n\"They accomplished something very important. Washington and Jefferson were central to the creation of a nation...Lee and Stonewall were not being honored for those types of accomplishments,\" Jim Grossman, the executive director of the American Historical Association told the Washington Post.\n\nThe debate over confederate statues was part of the fallout of the Charlottesville violence over the weekend, when white nationalist groups and anti-protesters clashed after the city council decided to remove a statue of Robert E. Lee from the city.\n\nA 32-year-old woman was rammed to death by a white nationalist with a car during the clash, sparking nation-wide furor.\n\nTrump attracted further criticism by saying both the
