{"timeCrawl": "02:55:00", "uri": "711219742", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:55:00Z", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/donald-trump-in-civil-war-with-his-own-party-over-confederate-monuments-36044156.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36044155.ece/7c7c3/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-eac30734-6d4f-416b-b5a2-83915ec6a347_I1.jpg\n\nDonald Trump has lashed out at members of his own party as his controversial response to white supremacist violence threatens to engulf his presidency.\n\nWith prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, Mr Trump returned to the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials, bemoaning efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture\".\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMr Trump was much quicker on Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a pavement and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a US general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\nThe president wrote: \"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\"\n\nMr Trump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behaviour has clearly begun to anger his Republican allies.\n\nSenator Bob Corker of Tennessee, who Mr Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises.\n\nAnd Senator Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted: \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSenator Tim Scott of South Carolina said the president's \"moral authority is compromised\".\n\nMr Trump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift focus from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E Lee. Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish.\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nMr T rump found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics towards a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils on Wednesday after the chief executive members began quitting.\n\nThat damaged his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nAnd the White House said on Thursday it was abandoning plans to form an infrastructure advisory council.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, cancelled fundraisers scheduled for Mr Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over the president's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying Mr Trump's chief economic adviser, Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, was not quitting.\n\nThe president h it back hard against Republicans, accusing \"publicity-seeking\" Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Mr Trump's position on the Charlottesville demonstrators.\n\nHe called Arizona Senator Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised his potential primary election opponent.\n\nMr Graham had said Mr Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute on Monday.\n\nThat was two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nBut he returned to his combative stance Tuesday - insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks.\n\nBut not all were unhappy with his performance, with adviser Steve Bannon telling allies that it would electrify the Republican Party base.\n\nHis job security in the White House is tenuous - Mr Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post - but Mr Bannon welcomed a fight over Confederate monuments.\n\nHe told The New York Times: \"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist. Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"", "id": "9812586", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Donald Trump in civil war with his own party over Confederate monuments", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36044155.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-eac30734-6d4f-416b-b5a2-83915ec6a347_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict"}, {"wgt": 100, "id": 705, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious Relations", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Race-Ethnic-Religious_Relations"}], "time": "02:55:00"}
{"timeCrawl": "09:36:00", "uri": "711362399", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:46:00Z", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "source": {"title": "Winston-Salem Journal", "uri": "journalnow.com", "id": "5036"}, "url": "http://www.journalnow.com/news/state_region/lawmakers-react-to-charlottesville-events-trump-statements/article_ab3a75f9-bbf6-5ee5-b15d-6e3fcd2d199c.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "U.S. Sen. Richard Burr, R-N.C., reacted Thursday to President Trump's tweets that the removal of Confederate statues around the country is foolish and would damage the nation's history and culture.\n\nBurr and U.S. Rep. David Price, D-4th, were the only members of the state's delegation to Congress who talked about Trump's most recent statements about Confederate monuments.\n\nBurr, some his fellow Republicans in the U.S. House and the state's three Democratic House members also have publicly discussed the Charlottesville events amid a renewed effort to remove Confederate statues from public property across the country.\n\nIn a series of tweets, Trump wrote partly that, \"the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\" He also tweeted, \"Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish!\"\n\nBurr told WXII Television in Greensboro that \"I'm not sure that removing every historical marker in America heals the country. That doesn't heal the country.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, Burr termed Trump's statement that both sides of the protesters in Charlottesville share equal blame for the violence \"misguided.\"\n\nMembers of the Ku Klux Klan, neo-Nazis and pro-Confederate groups gathered in Charlottesville last Saturday to rally against that city's decision to remove a statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee from a downtown park. Counterprotesters gathered to oppose the white nationalists' rally, and some members on both sides fought.\n\nHeather Heyer, 32, a counterprotester, was killed when a car plowed into counterprotesters after authorities broke up the white nationalist Unite the Right rally. James Alex Fields, 20, of Maumee, Ohio, and a Nazi sympathizer, has been charged with murder and other offenses in Heyer's death.\n\nSome Republican senators and House members have criticized Trump for failing to initially identify the white nationalist groups by name on Saturday. The president identified those groups Monday, but said again on Tuesday that both sides share equal blame for the violence in Charlottesville.\n\nIn the wake of Saturday's events, elected leaders in many cities and towns across the country have said that Confederate statues should be removed from public property. Gov. Roy Cooper, D-N.C., joined that chorus Wednesday as he called for the removal of all Confederate monuments on public property in North Carolina.\n\nIn addition, U.S. Rep. Alma Adams, D-12th, has called for the removal of Confederate statues in North Carolina and in Washington, D.C.\n\nCooper also said that a state law that requires state officials to approve any action to remove those statues should be repealed.\n\nU.S. Rep. Virginia Foxx, R-5th, pointed to her Saturday tweet about the mayhem in Charlottesville in which she said that the violence and bigotry displayed there was an affront to American values.\n\n\"My position on the attack of our shared American values remains unchanged,\" Foxx said in a statement Thursday. \"I am repulsed by the violence promulgated in Charlottesville by white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups.\n\n\"I offer my deepest condolences to the family of Heather Heyer, and I will continue to pray for all of those affected by the tragedy in Charlottesville,\" Foxx said.\n\nU.S. Rep. Mark Walker, R-6th, criticized right-wing hate groups in a statement.\n\n\"The message of white nationalists, supremacists and other groups that project hate is evil and contrary to God's call to love all mankind and that every life is valuable,\" Walker said. \"I hope the voices of Americans -- especially those of faith -- will be loud enough to drown out every voice of hate. As a state and as a nation, we should focus on the things and ideas that bring us together, rather than further division.\"\n\nPrice criticized Trump's tweets about the Confederate statues.\n\n\"What this president can't seem to comprehend is that the darkest parts of our history are best learned through teachers, textbooks, and museums, not statues put on pedestals in town squares and public buildings,\" Price said. \"Communities, including those in states like North Carolina, should be able to remove the icons they deem offensive without interference from the state legislature or reprimand from Donald Trump.\n\n\"We don't get to choose our history, but we do get to choose the history we celebrate,\" Price said.\n\nU.S. Rep. George Holding, R-2nd, said he condemned slavery, but he supports keeping the Confederate monuments in place.\n\n\"There are moments in American history we can point to with pride, and there are other moments when men made mistakes and when what they did was wrong,\" Holding said. \"And, often, the same men who did good also made mistakes.\n\n\"Slavery was one of our terrible mistakes,\" Holding said. \"It was wrong. But we also can be proud of how, at Appomattox, Lincoln and Grant and Lee put our country on the road to healing and unity.\n\n\"That is why I do not believe we should take down memorials to the soldiers who fought in the Civil War,\" Holding said. \"Instead, we should learn from history, as Lincoln said in 1865 a month before Appomattox, 'With malice toward none, with charity for all.'\"", Lee statue, armed with semi-automatic weapons and mace and chanting \"Jews will not replace us!\" and \"Blood and Soil!\"\n\nTrump, who previously said, during Tuesday's \"infrastructure\" press conference, that local governments should determine whether to remove confederate statues and symbols in their community, this morning tweeted his displeasure, in 10-minute-ish intervals, that several local governments had done just that. Lee And George Washington: No Difference argument he'd used earlier in the week at his unhinged Trump Tower press conference:\n\nAnd, finally, Trump warned that the \"beauty\" of effigies memorializing the war to break up the country or the sake of slavery \"will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\nPointedly, Baltimore's mayor had crews quietly remove four of the city's Confederate monuments, without notice, hours after Trump's Tuesday presser, at which he argued removing statues of Confederate leaders would lead to removal of monuments to George Washington.\n\nBaltimore Mayor Catherine E. Pugh had announced Monday she was in talks with contractors to haul away the statues, and the city council approved a removal plan that night, WaPo reported.\n\nTrump's morning tweets mark his latest stab at doing over his response to the deadly rally in Charlottesville, in which a woman was killed when a white supremacist plowed his car into demonstrators. Trump initially said there was fault \"on all sides\" - a statement for which he was widely blasted by government chiefs around the world, by Dems at home and even by Republicans. Source: SIPA USA/PA Images\n\nUS PRESIDENT DONALD Trump has added fuel to the debate over the removal of Confederate statues that led to the murder of a protester in Charlottesville.\n\nTrump tweeted this afternoon that the removal of US Civil War statues was \"foolish\" and he claimed that the \"history and culture\" of the United States was \"being ripped apart\".\n\nThe tweets came 24 hours after the funeral of Heather Heyer who was killed while attending a counter-protest against white supremacists who were protesting the removal of a Confederate statue in the city.\n\nHeyer was killed when a car ploughed into the protest she was attending.\n\nThe violence flared in Charlottesville when white supremacist activists, many of them armed, attempted to protest the removal of a large statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee from a park in the city.\n\nThe city's local council had voted to remove the statue and numerous similar statues around the US have been removed since.\n\nIn a series of tweets this afternoon, Trump said that he did not support the removal of the statues.\n\nSource: Donald J. Trump/Twitter\n\nSource: Donald J. Trump/Twitter\n\nSource: Donald J. Trump/Twitter\n\nTrump's referencing of George Washington echoed comments he made from a rambling press conference on Tuesday in which he questioned whether statues of the first president should be removed because he had owned slaves.\n\nHistorians have pointed out that while Washington owned slaves, he did not fight a war to maintain slavery, as is the case with General Lee.\n\nTrump's delayed response to the violence in Charlottesville was roundly criticised in the United States, as was his repeated contention that there was violence \"on both sides\".\n\nRead: Thousands hold vigil for {"timeCrawl": "23:25:00", "uri": "711161825", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:25:00Z", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "source": {"title": "wbrc.com", "uri": "wbrc.com", "id": "219"}, "url": "http://www.wbrc.com/story/36154958/under-fire-from-gop-trump-digs-in-on-confederate-icons", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) - With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons - bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard - against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday - insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous - Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post - but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n___\n\nLemire reported from New York. Associated Press writer Julie Bykowicz in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"timeCrawl": "22:44:00", "uri": "711149035", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:44:00Z", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "source": {"title": "PostBulletin.com", "uri": "postbulletin.com", "id": "3887"}, "url": "http://www.postbulletin.com/business/under-fire-from-gop-trump-digs-in-on-confederate-icons/article_247a8cc9-7c59-5a5c-aeaf-b6b339adc0dc.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators and called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance on Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n-- -- --\n\nLemire reported from New York. {"timeCrawl": "23:17:00", "uri": "711159566", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:17:00Z", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "source": {"title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-increasingly-isolated-business-panels-dismantled-074108264--politics.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) -- With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nTwo major charities, the Cleveland Clinic and the American Cancer Society, announced they are canceling fundraisers scheduled for Trump's resort in Palm Beach, Florida, amid the continuing backlash over Trump's remarks.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators. He called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n___\n\nLemire reported from New York. {"timeCrawl": "22:33:00", "uri": "711145731", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:33:00Z", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "source": {"title": "Bradenton Herald", "uri": "bradenton.com", "id": "2725"}, "url": "http://www.bradenton.com/news/business/article167682752.html", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons -- bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson -- who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard -- against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators and called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance on Tuesday -- insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous -- Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post -- but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. {"timeCrawl": "09:21:00", "uri": "711355590", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:42:00Z", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "source": {"title": "Standard Republic", "uri": "standardrepublic.com", "id": "18909"}, "url": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/2017/08/trump-sad-over-removal-of-our-beautiful-statues/25917.htm", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Under fire for defending racist activist groups, President Trump said on Twitter on Thursday that he was \"sad\" to see United States' history torn apart by the removal of \"our beautiful statues and monuments,\" echoing a popular refrain of white supremacist groups that oppose the removal of Confederate monuments.\n\nOfficials in several states have called for the removal of public monuments that have become symbols of the Confederacy.\n\nThe Twitter posts were the latest in his escalating remarks that critics contend validates white supremacist groups who led a bloody rally over the weekend in Charlottesville, Va. The proposed removal of a statute of the Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee from a public park in Charlottesville spurred the demonstrations.", "id": "9860615", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Trump 'Sad' Over Removal of 'Our Beautiful Statues' - Standard Republic", "image": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/18dc-trump-facebookJumbo.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "concepts": [{"location": {"label": {"eng": "United States"}, "type": "country"}, "score": 3, "id": "233", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "type": "loc"}, {"location": {"country": {"label": {"eng": "United States"}, "type": "country"}, "label": {"eng": "Charlottesville"}, "type": "place"}, "score": 2, "id": "200134", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlottesville,_Virginia", "label": {"eng": "Charlottesville"}, "type": "loc"}, {"label": {"eng": "Twitter"}, "id": "302546", "score": 4, "type": "org", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"}, {"label": {"eng": "Racism"}, "id": "302940", "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racism"}, {"label": {"eng": "President of the United States"}, "id": "304262", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States"}, {"label": {"eng": "U.S. state"}, "id": "305165", "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._state"}, {"label": {"eng": "Confederate States of America"}, "id": "305960", "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America"}, {"label": {"eng": "White supremacy"}, "id": "305969", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_supremacy"}, {"label": {"eng": "Statute"}, "id": "308452", "score": 1, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statute"}, {"label": {"eng": "Thursday (band)"}, "id": "358576", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thursday_(band)"}, {"label": {"eng": "Robert E. {"timeCrawl": "22:27:00", "uri": "711143248", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:27:00Z", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "source": {"title": "KHNL TV 8", "uri": "hawaiinewsnow.com", "id": "11710"}, "url": "http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36154959/under-fire-from-gop-trump-digs-in-on-confederate-icons", "eventUri": "eng-3369066", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3369066", "body": "BRIDGEWATER, N.J. (AP) - With prominent Republicans openly questioning his competence and moral leadership, President Donald Trump on Thursday burrowed deeper into the racially charged debate over Confederate memorials and lashed out at members of his own party in the latest controversy to engulf his presidency.\n\nOut of sight, but still online, Trump tweeted his defense of monuments to Confederate icons - bemoaning rising efforts to remove them as an attack on America's \"history and culture.\"\n\nAnd he berated his critics who, with increasingly sharper language, have denounced his initially slow and then ultimately combative comments on the racial violence at a white supremacist rally last weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump was much quicker Thursday to condemn violence in Barcelona, where more than a dozen people were killed when a van veered onto a sidewalk and sped down a busy pedestrian zone in what authorities called a terror attack.\n\nHe then added to his expression of support a tweet reviving a debunked legend about a U.S. general subduing Muslim rebels a century ago in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in pig blood.\n\n\"Study what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught. There was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTrump's unpredictable, defiant and, critics claim, racially provocative behavior has clearly begun to wear on his Republican allies.\n\nTennessee Sen. Bob Corker, whom Trump considered for a Cabinet post, declared Thursday that \"the president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability nor some of the competence that he needs to\" in dealing with crises. And Sen. Dan Sullivan of Alaska tweeted, \"Anything less than complete & unambiguous condemnation of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and the KKK by the @POTUS is unacceptable. Period.\"\n\nSen. Tim Scott of South Carolina said Trump's \"moral authority is compromised.\"\n\nTrump, who is known to try to change the focus of news coverage with an attention-grabbing declaration, sought to shift Thursday from the white supremacists to the future of statues.\n\n\"You can't change history, but you can learn from it,\" he tweeted. \"Robert E. Lee. Stonewall Jackson - who's next, Washington, Jefferson? So foolish. ...\n\n\"Also the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!\"\n\n\"Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump met separately Thursday at his golf club in nearby Bedminster with the administrator of the Small Business Administration and Florida Gov. Rick Scott, a longtime Trump supporter. Trump also prepared for an unusual meeting Friday at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland with his national security team to discuss strategy for South Asia, including India, Pakistan and Afghanistan.\n\nVice President Mike Pence was cutting short a long-planned Latin America tour to attend the meeting.\n\nThough out of public view, Trump sought to make his voice heard on Twitter as he found himself increasingly under siege and alone while fanning the controversy over race and politics toward a full-fledged national conflagration.\n\nHe dissolved two business councils Wednesday after the CEO members began quitting, damaging his central campaign promise to be a business-savvy chief executive in the Oval Office.\n\nMeanwhile, rumblings of discontent from his staff grew so loud that the White House had to release a statement saying that Trump's chief economic adviser wasn't quitting. And the president remained on the receiving end of bipartisan criticism for his handling of the aftermath of the Charlottesville clashes.\n\nOn Thursday, he hit back hard - against Republicans.\n\nHe accused \"publicity-seeking\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina of falsely stating Trump's position on the demonstrators and called Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake \"toxic\" and praised Flake's potential primary election opponent.\n\nGraham said Wednesday that Trump \"took a step backward by again suggesting there is moral equivalency\" between the marching white supremacists and the people who had been demonstrating against them. Flake has been increasingly critical of Trump in recent weeks.\n\nPressured by advisers, the president had softened his words on the dispute Monday, two days after he had enraged many by declining to single out the white supremacists and neo-Nazis whose demonstration against the removal of a Robert E. Lee statute had led to violence and the death of a counter-protester in Charlottesville.\n\nHe returned to his combative stance on Tuesday - insisting anew during an unexpected and contentious news conference at Trump Tower that \"both sides\" were to blame.\n\nAides watching from the sidelines reacted with dismay and disbelief and privately told colleagues they were upset by the president's remarks, though not upset enough for anyone to resign.\n\nThe resignation speculation around Gary Cohn, head of the National Economic Council and a Jew, had grown so intense by Thursday that the White House released a statement saying reports that Cohn was stepping down were \"100 percent false.\"\n\nBut not all of Trump's aides were unhappy with his performance.\n\nAdviser Steve Bannon's job security in the White House has become tenuous - Trump offered only a \"we'll see\" on Tuesday when asked if his chief strategist would remain in his post - but Bannon has been telling allies that the president's news conference would electrify the GOP base.\n\nAnd in a pair of interviews Wednesday, Bannon cheered on the president's nationalist tendencies and suggested that a fight over Confederate monuments was a political fight he welcomes.\n\n\"The race-identity politics of the left wants to say it's all racist,\" Bannon told The New York Times. \"Just give me more. Tear down more statues. Say the revolution is coming. I can't get enough of it.\"\n\n___\n\nLemire reported from New York. Associated Press writer Julie Bykowicz in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
